e78e8c97-131f-4172-a5ad-ad97ab9fc7af.summary: What is freedom (in the sense of liberty)?
e78e8c97-131f-4172-a5ad-ad97ab9fc7af.content: What is freedom (in the sense of liberty)?

c5b5563f-c42f-44bc-85d2-12c5de6cc0e1.content: {Freedom is the absence of external constraints}, {A person is free if they are not prevented by others from doing what they want}

73501273-2db3-4bbf-9639-f7e4dcab7a0d.content: {Freedom is the ability to be one's own master}, {A person is free if they can pursue their own rational will}

4e3783a2-f610-4d5f-9a13-69cac944c2cc.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination}, {A person is free if they are not subject to arbitrary interference by others}

74651805-45f0-4640-b302-8bc6d82f3533.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated}

a0431795-2c99-4f8c-90a6-a242eb509308.content: {Freedom is self-governance}, {A person is free if they can make their own choices without coercion}

87def8f6-70d7-4685-bc9f-0964b4dec30a.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable functionings}, {A person is free if they have the capabilities to pursue a life they have reason to value}

0509358e-71d4-403b-a62d-79599318e0a9.content: {Freedom is participation in community life}, {A person is free if they can engage in communal decision-making processes}

39d64ce6-e643-4857-93d5-0a03aaaca1ea.content: {Freedom is the creation of one's own essence}, {A person is free if they can define their own identity and purpose}

458a8307-ce73-45b4-b4a3-544a59db7de4.content: {Freedom is equal access to opportunities}, {A person is free if they have the same opportunities as others to pursue their goals}

b8e974ba-bf5f-453a-a867-17b3f0bc7da8.content: {Freedom is limited only by the prevention of harm to others}, {A person is free if they can act as they wish as long as they do not harm others}

af3a6a26-4861-4391-bd47-aa69044f41b0.content: {Freedom is acting in accordance with moral law}, {A person is free if they act according to moral principles they autonomously endorse}

a64e1769-ab90-4486-8f71-192d8d80e0a9.content: {Freedom is compatible with determinism}, {A person is free if their actions align with their desires, even if those desires are determined}

8cb4d571-7523-4340-a688-35c1e1d87466.content: {Freedom is the absence of interference}, {A person is free if others do not interfere with their actions}

052aeeaa-f961-49a7-8bdc-b5160173d214.content: {Freedom is derived from social agreements}, {A person is free if they live under laws they have consented to}

a2c8fa1e-109a-407c-988f-3342ff96d77a.content: {Freedom is acting according to rational will}, {A person is free if they act in accordance with their rational deliberations}

f27e4a4b-54a9-4dfc-97e4-861a89044546.content: {Freedom is the practical ability to achieve goals}, {A person is free if they can effectively pursue their objectives}

bd9f68b1-bdcc-4b91-86ad-fcb22faf87a5.content: {Freedom is the collective self-determination of a group}, {A group is free if it can determine its own political and social structures}

72bfec3a-b1ab-414f-bcdc-8cae2a2ae756.content: {Freedom is the realization of one's true self}, {A person is free if they can develop and express their authentic self}

9cb09c09-676c-4eef-be9c-6163aae57c6f.content: {Freedom is the ability to maintain one's cultural identity}, {A person is free if they can preserve and express their cultural heritage}

8dd51c18-835e-49ef-b64f-a4ff75941858.content: {Freedom is the ability to engage in economic activities}, {A person is free if they can participate in the market without undue restriction}

b13fffe0-ee02-41f7-9970-d02cd95abdb3.content: {Individuals can make their own choices without external interference}, {Autonomy is valued as a fundamental aspect of human dignity}

e698c16e-30c7-4009-8862-8e28413d4682.content: {External constraints prevent individuals from acting according to their own desires}, {Freedom is diminished when individuals are restricted by others}

c91ced0f-5497-4a8a-abbe-92d95548a14b.content: {Non-interference allows individuals to pursue their own goals}, {Freedom is understood as the ability to act without being hindered by others}

e46c1de7-48a3-4904-8dbb-0e1d69f75c44.summary: Freedom involves the ability to act on desires
e46c1de7-48a3-4904-8dbb-0e1d69f75c44.content: {A person is free when they can act on their desires without obstruction}, {Freedom is related to the capacity to fulfill one's own wishes}

f0e5ae58-fa24-4480-814d-817ee2883188.content: {Coercion involves forcing someone to act against their will}, {Freedom is reduced when individuals are coerced by others}

b0ab4bd7-19d5-43e7-ab6f-4cd3d4ba8148.summary: Freedom requires absence of physical barriers
b0ab4bd7-19d5-43e7-ab6f-4cd3d4ba8148.content: {Physical barriers prevent individuals from moving freely}, {Freedom is associated with the ability to move without physical restrictions}

0ff58185-f2a8-4579-95c4-28599a90f855.content: {Legal restrictions can prevent individuals from engaging in certain activities}, {Freedom is curtailed when laws impose unnecessary constraints}

6ecf2440-82c4-4291-a912-f837b46c3416.content: {Social norms can pressure individuals to conform}, {Freedom is limited when social expectations dictate behavior}

d610c0d4-010a-46f6-8568-94b1825cd03a.content: {Having multiple options allows individuals to choose freely}, {Freedom is linked to the availability of choices}

886f01e2-7dd1-4327-b57d-0013a84af2ff.content: {Surveillance can deter individuals from acting freely}, {Freedom is compromised when individuals feel constantly watched}

d1e884f5-aaac-4ce7-9b59-de31c0e5eb24.content: {Self-determination involves making decisions for oneself}, {Freedom is connected to the ability to determine one's own actions}

83c9f084-f4d7-4458-920b-1f437f82f0c8.content: {Domination involves control over others}, {Freedom is reduced when individuals are dominated by others}

dddfc553-4e2b-4047-9cb1-b9fecf4f99ce.summary: Freedom is linked to personal responsibility
dddfc553-4e2b-4047-9cb1-b9fecf4f99ce.content: {Personal responsibility involves being accountable for one's actions}, {Freedom includes the ability to take responsibility for one's choices}

8df35031-1722-4564-b2e8-5366870f81de.content: {Paternalism involves restricting freedom for someone's own good}, {Freedom is diminished when others decide what is best for an individual}

4477091f-3db5-43c4-9614-379c37b41a85.content: {Non-coercive relationships allow individuals to interact freely}, {Freedom is enhanced when relationships are based on mutual consent}

31f14cad-b4ec-4f61-9d90-e6519f88b7b5.summary: Freedom is linked to the absence of oppression
31f14cad-b4ec-4f61-9d90-e6519f88b7b5.content: {Oppression involves unjust treatment or control}, {Freedom is compromised when individuals are oppressed by others}

8f834663-97b2-4e74-a1f9-b99317d3dbcd.summary: Freedom is about the absence of arbitrary power
8f834663-97b2-4e74-a1f9-b99317d3dbcd.content: {Arbitrary power involves making decisions without justification}, {Freedom is threatened when individuals are subject to arbitrary authority}

b1e1f303-a5c3-437b-91c1-6c4604f5a4f8.summary: Freedom involves the absence of censorship
b1e1f303-a5c3-437b-91c1-6c4604f5a4f8.content: {Censorship restricts the flow of information}, {Freedom is linked to the ability to express oneself without censorship}

7b389b96-385e-404b-9fd5-deaee646ee02.summary: Freedom is about the absence of economic constraints
7b389b96-385e-404b-9fd5-deaee646ee02.content: {Economic constraints can limit individuals' ability to act freely}, {Freedom is related to having the resources to pursue one's goals}

2f82bff9-858d-4c12-8a44-0b99394ee6a1.summary: Freedom is linked to the absence of fear
2f82bff9-858d-4c12-8a44-0b99394ee6a1.content: {Fear can prevent individuals from acting freely}, {Freedom is enhanced when individuals do not live in fear of repercussions}

999a23ca-e2f3-4c36-a29b-17e1227543dc.content: {Freedom involves the capacity to make autonomous decisions}, {Autonomy requires the ability to reflect on and choose one's own goals}

094cf87d-47f8-4def-aaf9-587c6f0880b7.content: {A person is free if they can act according to their rational will}, {Rational will involves making choices based on reason rather than impulse}

87fd6fab-6115-4521-8101-5b91a0d288eb.content: {Self-determination is a key aspect of freedom}, {Being able to determine one's own path is essential to being free}

5425da42-13bb-4d5f-b3f0-76582af126d4.content: {Freedom can be limited by internal constraints such as ignorance or irrational desires}, {Overcoming internal constraints is necessary for true freedom}

ce855699-a3c5-46ab-84e1-50411b0d64b4.content: {Moral responsibility requires the ability to act freely}, {Freedom involves the capacity to make moral choices}

ccadc798-a9e7-48ca-b528-8d6392e86b5f.content: {Personal development is linked to the ability to pursue one's own goals}, {Freedom is necessary for personal growth and self-improvement}

98916c2b-d439-4f5a-a9b3-506591a84c75.content: {Self-realization involves achieving one's potential}, {Freedom is the ability to pursue self-realization}

8e64aeee-bd8b-46b8-8b08-16e9bf983f48.content: {Freedom involves being free from external control or coercion}, {External control can limit one's ability to act according to their rational will}

6fa87fde-55fe-4167-a92c-34205d1cd5c3.content: {Authenticity involves being true to oneself}, {Freedom is the ability to live authentically}

9ec9f128-bd3f-45f1-9ce5-738f1da2f422.content: {Rational deliberation is necessary for making autonomous choices}, {Freedom involves the capacity for rational deliberation}

670c4d67-406d-4343-b00e-8c853e447d52.content: {Self-governance is the ability to govern oneself}, {Freedom involves the capacity for self-governance}

081f6fe0-3bfb-4190-9e4d-3c70fdb9040b.content: {Moral autonomy involves making moral decisions independently}, {Freedom is necessary for moral autonomy}

13c1c84d-51f5-4c66-8296-24f08554ca2d.content: {Self-control is the ability to regulate one's own actions}, {Freedom involves having self-control}

52114a86-6308-4234-9cfa-c1fa22f8b7ac.content: {Critical reflection is necessary for making informed choices}, {Freedom involves the capacity for critical reflection}

f478716e-60ee-45dc-8908-83957ef062f9.content: {Individuality involves being true to one's own nature}, {Freedom is the ability to express one's individuality}

edb32400-292b-4535-844a-7c01c7e9a3ea.content: {Personal agency is the capacity to act independently}, {Freedom involves having personal agency}

e91c2787-817b-4c53-8594-6dd1979e901f.content: {Empowerment involves having the ability to make choices}, {Freedom is necessary for empowerment}

52598164-6516-4023-b8d9-ffc4ae8c9e9f.content: {Self-fulfillment involves achieving personal satisfaction}, {Freedom is the ability to pursue self-fulfillment}

140919b2-9f93-4adc-9dca-a88984955867.content: {Self-awareness is necessary for understanding one's own desires}, {Freedom involves having self-awareness}

bec55ac2-789b-42fc-a1af-d6438fd879fd.content: {Self-ownership involves having control over one's own life}, {Freedom is the ability to exercise self-ownership}

671ee4c0-dc4c-4426-9c2d-396f16c89aa6.content: {There is an intuition that true freedom involves not being dominated by others}, {Domination implies a power imbalance that restricts autonomy}

1c27a023-14c1-46f5-aa84-a2d533c27a2b.content: {Arbitrary interference by others can undermine an individual's autonomy}, {Autonomy is a key component of personal freedom}

5f7dd4bf-abc1-49c6-96d0-3f76ca88109c.content: {Power dynamics in relationships can affect an individual's freedom}, {Being subject to another's will can limit one's ability to act freely}

2334b702-69b9-4d55-8efd-31c327272643.content: {Freedom requires security from interference by others}, {Security from interference allows individuals to pursue their own goals}

1444031e-0e64-400c-8b6b-cd39e3e20444.content: {Social structures can perpetuate domination}, {Domination within social structures can limit individual freedom}

7db55e21-f9a7-4d5d-a843-215b49a80d66.summary: Legal systems can protect against domination
7db55e21-f9a7-4d5d-a843-215b49a80d66.content: {Legal systems can protect individuals from domination}, {Protection from domination can enhance personal freedom}

f4b0fd7c-2b74-4010-8653-37d4a71e8c59.content: {Consent is crucial for maintaining freedom}, {Without consent, actions imposed by others can be seen as domination}

f9df0ffc-0cae-447b-a56a-de0d131aa022.content: {Freedom involves the ability to make choices without coercion}, {Coercion by others can be a form of domination}

c1daf656-3a17-4070-8407-2c6bf75e6069.content: {Not all interference is arbitrary}, {Non-arbitrary interference may not constitute domination}

a36bdfa5-168c-46a0-aa83-b96eec3b460f.content: {Historical examples show how domination restricts freedom}, {Examples of domination include slavery and authoritarian rule}

c0e14b09-d8e6-4f7b-b8a9-1252bf63515e.content: {Domination can have a psychological impact on individuals}, {Psychological effects of domination can include loss of self-esteem and agency}

f83bd198-76be-4b0d-82d8-aabc49a8f239.summary: Economic power can lead to domination
f83bd198-76be-4b0d-82d8-aabc49a8f239.content: {Economic power can lead to domination}, {Economic domination can restrict individuals' freedom to make choices}

527eaa61-a478-4f50-b765-969de7384194.content: {Cultural norms can enforce domination}, {Domination through cultural norms can limit personal freedom}

9d49fe0f-96fa-4439-861f-a4a65b234da2.summary: Freedom as non-domination aligns with democratic values
9d49fe0f-96fa-4439-861f-a4a65b234da2.content: {Freedom as non-domination aligns with democratic values}, {Democratic values emphasize equality and protection from arbitrary power}

d4c97cc6-d27b-450a-afa6-4335049a2ea8.summary: Domination can be subtle and systemic
d4c97cc6-d27b-450a-afa6-4335049a2ea8.content: {Domination can be subtle and systemic}, {Systemic domination can be harder to identify and resist}

50109fb9-c785-4323-93e1-7ee66a2d4df7.content: {Non-domination allows for genuine agency}, {Genuine agency is essential for personal freedom}

d9d2dd53-f683-4111-8189-b52f53e7e981.content: {Interpersonal relationships can involve domination}, {Domination in relationships can limit personal freedom}

0b0a1ed8-dd71-46cf-b567-4ac178584f78.summary: Freedom involves more than just lack of interference
0b0a1ed8-dd71-46cf-b567-4ac178584f78.content: {Freedom involves more than just lack of interference}, {True freedom requires absence of domination}

af7ee61a-0538-4d2a-998c-db44613992ff.content: {Non-domination promotes equality}, {Equality is a fundamental aspect of a free society}

9bcb6f8f-c8f1-43e5-8a62-42d939255cd9.content: {Individuals have an intuition that they own themselves}, {This intuition suggests that individuals have inherent rights over their own bodies and actions}

a2c117f6-90ff-4fdf-b7a1-2e4b56e260a3.content: {There is a strong intuition that consent is morally significant}, {Violating someone's consent is often seen as a moral wrong}

15e4d838-9090-4d68-812f-80e3ffdf9bb1.content: {Personal autonomy is widely valued as a fundamental aspect of human dignity}, {Respecting autonomy involves allowing individuals to make their own choices}

8dcf4479-57a2-45b2-81ab-bc07da8dd6a0.content: {Voluntary exchange is seen as a cornerstone of fair economic interactions}, {Transactions are considered just when all parties consent freely}

81791cec-ca5c-44bc-9cc0-fb399cdd8c6a.content: {There is an intuition that initiating force against others is morally wrong}, {This principle supports the idea that individuals should not be coerced}

181d8c55-ce2f-4c87-b634-8013e260ad55.content: {Property rights are often seen as essential for personal security and freedom}, {Respecting property rights is considered a way to respect individual autonomy}

df091c5f-196a-4e89-bd99-4d032f59bc69.content: {There is a strong intuition that contracts should be honored}, {Breaking a contract without consent is often viewed as unjust}

9a125c6a-5406-4415-a72f-2116fe4c8f96.content: {Individuals are generally seen as responsible for their own actions}, {This responsibility implies that individuals should bear the consequences of their choices}

904ef0e3-c2d5-4b1c-b94b-0789cde06d30.content: {There is a widespread intuition that theft is morally wrong}, {Taking someone's property without permission is seen as a violation of their rights}

7eaad091-4163-405b-8d89-2e8bf6768f54.content: {Self-determination is considered a fundamental human right}, {Allowing individuals to determine their own lives is seen as respecting their freedom}

3eb6ec49-1991-4c4d-b60f-1da7ac9f1215.content: {There is an intuition that wrongs should be rectified through restitution}, {Compensating victims is seen as a way to restore justice}

76935ad2-cced-48e9-ac2a-7c240050693f.content: {Promises are generally seen as morally binding}, {Breaking a promise without justification is often viewed as a moral failing}

35a0f2ef-e130-4306-86ce-af7e86619971.content: {There is an intuition that actions should not harm others}, {This principle suggests that individuals should be free to act as long as they do not harm others}

c4231ea8-42e6-4fb1-84a2-a8ca8da7b66b.content: {Freedom of association is considered a fundamental right}, {Individuals should be free to choose with whom they associate}

fd6f8029-8684-4429-92f6-f95f239b3d96.content: {There is a strong intuition that coercion is morally wrong}, {Forcing someone to act against their will is seen as a violation of their freedom}

dbeb3453-53df-4016-bbed-2d1bd04928cb.content: {Individual choice is often seen as central to personal freedom}, {Respecting choice involves allowing individuals to pursue their own goals}

f1685b1a-bec0-44f7-bab9-5fe841f0f26c.summary: Intuition of equality before the law

366ceccf-3714-4d9e-a10d-a418e971eb3c.content: {Free speech is considered a fundamental right}, {Allowing individuals to express their opinions is seen as essential for personal freedom}

de616bdd-3342-4691-8ace-e6b154811909.content: {There is an intuition that self-defense is morally permissible}, {Defending oneself against aggression is seen as a legitimate exercise of rights}

b7554bdd-72cb-4a97-bbce-2d888b8ca830.content: {There is an intuition that state intervention should be minimal}, {Excessive government control is often seen as a threat to individual freedom}

2543441b-3e39-4ed7-a30d-2be7f91ddb6e.content: {There is an intuition that freedom involves the ability to determine one's own actions}, {Self-determination is seen as a core aspect of personal freedom}

f6ccbc38-65cd-4415-bfd6-d1fefc8123dd.content: {There is a strong intuition that coercion limits freedom}, {Coercion involves external forces overriding personal choice}

30a3e333-5c3d-41c7-9f2a-71930c9b9c03.content: {The ability to make choices is fundamental to the concept of freedom}, {Without the ability to choose, the notion of freedom is compromised}

66b52a8a-f426-4b10-ad05-2d1152a9c490.summary: Autonomy is linked to moral responsibility
66b52a8a-f426-4b10-ad05-2d1152a9c490.content: {There is an intuition that autonomy is necessary for moral responsibility}, {Without autonomy, individuals cannot be held accountable for their actions}

47adcfae-a547-465b-93d1-e5523ce1b5ab.summary: Freedom requires absence of external control
47adcfae-a547-465b-93d1-e5523ce1b5ab.content: {Freedom is often understood as the absence of external control}, {External control is seen as a barrier to personal freedom}

2e006906-7479-4273-85dd-61cbfb7451bb.summary: Personal agency is essential for freedom
2e006906-7479-4273-85dd-61cbfb7451bb.content: {Personal agency is a key component of freedom}, {Without personal agency, individuals cannot be considered free}

f8ccd33c-fd3f-48cf-b04f-4c291fad634c.summary: Freedom is tied to individual rights
f8ccd33c-fd3f-48cf-b04f-4c291fad634c.content: {There is an intuition that freedom is closely tied to individual rights}, {Individual rights protect the ability to make personal choices}

f597be78-68ce-49e9-8645-9511e74b3fc2.summary: Self-governance is a form of freedom
f597be78-68ce-49e9-8645-9511e74b3fc2.content: {Self-governance is often equated with freedom}, {The ability to govern oneself is seen as a manifestation of being free}

1d3b9a91-642e-4d14-bb7d-fbd45d1a6617.summary: Freedom involves the capacity for self-expression
1d3b9a91-642e-4d14-bb7d-fbd45d1a6617.content: {The capacity for self-expression is considered a part of freedom}, {Without the ability to express oneself, freedom is restricted}

b5764810-f5bb-4ba5-beb4-1d4cd9d75ac5.content: {Autonomy is seen as essential for personal development}, {Personal development is hindered without the freedom to make one's own choices}

f4faeafb-a75b-4603-8432-aa4b10174caa.content: {Self-realization is often linked to the concept of freedom}, {The ability to realize one's potential is seen as a form of freedom}

f3a73207-8d53-4a8a-a432-9d4e8c718ed0.summary: Freedom is a condition for authentic living
f3a73207-8d53-4a8a-a432-9d4e8c718ed0.content: {Authentic living is often associated with freedom}, {Without freedom, living authentically is not possible}

0d22b59b-72cb-42ca-8933-1d6dc9aa7816.summary: Freedom is necessary for pursuing personal goals
0d22b59b-72cb-42ca-8933-1d6dc9aa7816.content: {The pursuit of personal goals is dependent on freedom}, {Without freedom, individuals cannot effectively pursue their own goals}

57cfb065-9acf-48b3-9017-f00be1e04887.summary: Freedom involves the absence of domination
57cfb065-9acf-48b3-9017-f00be1e04887.content: {The absence of domination is considered a component of freedom}, {Domination is seen as a constraint on personal freedom}

ac23c7a9-35b6-4df7-a37f-02b41ab6c73f.summary: Freedom allows for diverse life choices
ac23c7a9-35b6-4df7-a37f-02b41ab6c73f.content: {The ability to make diverse life choices is a part of freedom}, {Without freedom, the range of life choices is limited}

8c75fe9a-bf78-4f85-8f79-12474c9e31df.summary: Freedom is essential for personal happiness
8c75fe9a-bf78-4f85-8f79-12474c9e31df.content: {Personal happiness is often associated with freedom}, {Without freedom, achieving personal happiness is difficult}

8ce60101-332f-4665-8146-a4a2f1ef917a.content: {People have diverse conceptions of what constitutes a valuable life}, {Freedom should account for the ability to pursue one's own conception of a valuable life}

ba10950d-837d-46c4-af29-1520569230a6.content: {Having options is not sufficient for freedom if one lacks the capability to pursue them}, {Capabilities enable individuals to effectively pursue their chosen life paths}

3a723bdc-2bb5-4cca-90ff-8ad16f1139b9.content: {Functionings refer to the various things a person may value doing or being}, {Achieving valuable functionings is integral to a person's well-being}

c26d54e3-149c-4b0e-a45d-e3213d3cd6f9.content: {A person's freedom is influenced by their social and economic environment}, {Improving social and economic conditions can enhance individual capabilities}

9dd9d1d4-58a7-46a1-85c4-dec0f8a4f829.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is addicted to a substance and cannot stop using it despite wanting to. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves the ability to act according to one's own desires and rational deliberations. This principle together with the idea that addiction is an internal constraint entails that internal constraints can affect freedom.}

1011c601-2e33-4201-b1e1-29d0ff2d4256.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is manipulated into wanting something against their prior values and desires. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not free. If we say the person is free, then we ignore the impact of manipulation on autonomy. If we say the person is not free, then external constraints are not the only factors affecting freedom.}

b246f1c2-76b8-430f-8936-87f4513b18c3.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is not directly prevented by others from doing what they want, but social norms and expectations strongly discourage certain actions. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not entirely free.}, {It is implausible that freedom is solely about the absence of direct external constraints, as social structures can significantly limit one's real options.}

286d8ae9-ff5c-4f40-be74-70eff9b04de6.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves not just the ability to perform actions but also the ability to form one's own desires and preferences. This principle together with the idea that desires can be shaped by external influences entails that freedom is not only about actions.}

dc45cc48-c58d-453a-85f3-1735c754db68.summary: Does coercion affect freedom even without physical constraints?
dc45cc48-c58d-453a-85f3-1735c754db68.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is coerced into making a decision through threats that do not involve physical constraints. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free.}, {It is implausible that freedom is only about the absence of physical constraints, as coercion can limit freedom without physical barriers.}

f2cc3b4c-d7f8-4464-97db-aae7750907bd.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is unaware of certain options available to them due to lack of information. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not free. If we say the person is free, then we ignore the role of knowledge in making free choices. If we say the person is not free, then freedom involves more than just the absence of external constraints.}

94fba6da-4bad-4b2c-bfbe-f58d3008ffe4.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is not prevented by others from doing what they want, but economic inequality severely limits their opportunities. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not fully free.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves having genuine opportunities to pursue one's goals. This principle together with the impact of economic inequality entails that economic factors can affect freedom.}

0a77bdb5-6fba-4d73-b23a-9bb75c3ec85b.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the ability to have acted otherwise. This principle together with the idea that determinism implies all actions are predetermined entails that freedom may not be compatible with determinism.}

ed098506-f2dd-417c-ba3e-12cea75425bc.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is subjected to psychological manipulation that alters their desires without their awareness. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free.}, {It is implausible that freedom is solely about the absence of external constraints, as psychological manipulation can undermine autonomy.}

8bc86ad2-c832-4c78-868c-17131b3fa980.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves self-mastery or control over one's own desires and impulses. This principle together with the idea that self-mastery can be compromised by internal factors entails that freedom requires more than just the absence of external constraints.}

5bf06243-af52-431d-a9bd-0049a8ebfa31.summary: Can freedom be restricted by internal constraints?
5bf06243-af52-431d-a9bd-0049a8ebfa31.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is addicted to a substance and cannot stop using it despite wanting to. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free, even though they are acting according to their own will.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires not only the ability to pursue one's rational will but also the absence of internal constraints that prevent rational decision-making. This principle together with the scenario of addiction entails that a person may not be free even if they can pursue their own rational will.}

13fbf0ad-1bf6-4664-b31e-1121ed9b0285.summary: Does the concept of rational will exclude certain desires?
13fbf0ad-1bf6-4664-b31e-1121ed9b0285.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has a strong desire to engage in self-destructive behavior, which they rationalize as part of their rational will. Intuitively, we either have to say that their desire is part of their rational will or that it is not. If we say it is part of their rational will, then it seems counterintuitive to consider them free when pursuing self-destruction. If we say it is not part of their rational will, then we must exclude certain desires from being considered rational, which complicates the notion of freedom.}

95404085-6d78-42c6-bbf5-a5a4f587a404.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is subject to intense propaganda that shapes their rational will to align with an oppressive regime. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free, even though they are pursuing their own rational will.}, {It is implausible that freedom can exist when a person's rational will is heavily influenced by external forces that manipulate their desires and beliefs.}

128cf7f4-581d-461a-8df4-fa680a4a7509.summary: Is freedom compatible with irrational desires?
128cf7f4-581d-461a-8df4-fa680a4a7509.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves acting in accordance with reason rather than merely following any desire. This principle together with the idea that a person can have irrational desires entails that a person may not be free if they act on irrational desires.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person chooses to act on a whim that contradicts their long-term goals. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not exercising true freedom, as their actions are not aligned with rational deliberation.}

6fa0b973-3082-410f-b9d6-1b9e2f3c23f9.summary: Does the concept of positive liberty allow for paternalism?
6fa0b973-3082-410f-b9d6-1b9e2f3c23f9.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a government enforces laws that restrict individual choices for the sake of promoting citizens' rational will. Intuitively, we either have to say that such laws enhance freedom or that they restrict it. If we say they enhance freedom, then we must accept that paternalistic interventions can be justified under the guise of promoting rational will. If we say they restrict freedom, then the concept of positive liberty may conflict with individual autonomy.}

5ee7e751-a789-4643-8785-2841103ae781.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person acts according to their rational will but lacks self-awareness of their motivations and desires. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not fully free, as they are not consciously directing their actions.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires self-awareness and reflection on one's desires and motivations. This principle together with the scenario of lacking self-awareness entails that a person may not be free even if they act according to their rational will.}

f8167280-8325-4dc9-879c-5734597cf21a.summary: Is freedom dependent on moral responsibility?
f8167280-8325-4dc9-879c-5734597cf21a.content: {It is implausible that a person can be considered free if they are not morally responsible for their actions.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person is coerced into making a decision that aligns with their rational will but absolves them of moral responsibility. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free, as they are not accountable for their actions.}

f852eb1f-796e-4bbb-ac57-7d3cb45e0207.summary: Does freedom require the possibility of acting otherwise?
f852eb1f-796e-4bbb-ac57-7d3cb45e0207.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves the ability to choose between different courses of action. This principle together with the idea that a person may be determined to act in a specific way by their rational will entails that a person may not be free if they cannot act otherwise.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person is determined by their rational will to pursue a single course of action without alternatives. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person lacks freedom, as they have no genuine choice.}

4b8283d5-bb8f-424e-b447-b19194951869.summary: Can freedom be realized in isolation from social conditions?
4b8283d5-bb8f-424e-b447-b19194951869.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is isolated from society and has no opportunity to pursue their rational will due to lack of resources or social interaction. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free, as their ability to act is severely limited.}, {It is implausible that freedom can be fully realized without considering the social conditions that enable or restrict the pursuit of one's rational will.}

d4a1bbb3-74cf-4702-9624-507b4e669909.summary: Is the pursuit of rational will sufficient for freedom?
d4a1bbb3-74cf-4702-9624-507b4e669909.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires not only the pursuit of rational will but also the achievement of one's goals. This principle together with the idea that a person may pursue their rational will without achieving their goals entails that a person may not be free if they cannot realize their aims.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person diligently pursues their rational will but is constantly thwarted by external circumstances. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free, as their efforts do not lead to success.}

d43469f3-8441-4774-9d19-cae1c2e432db.summary: Can freedom exist without the possibility of interference?
d43469f3-8441-4774-9d19-cae1c2e432db.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person lives in a society where no one interferes with their actions, but the potential for interference is ever-present. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires not just the absence of interference, but also the absence of the potential for interference. This principle together with the presence of potential interference entails that the person is not free.}

d3cfecbc-facd-4832-9eb2-6be7e6e4b83e.summary: Is freedom compatible with benevolent interference?
d3cfecbc-facd-4832-9eb2-6be7e6e4b83e.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is subject to interference by others, but this interference is always benevolent and in the person's best interest. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is not free or that they are free. If we say the person is not free, then benevolent interference is incompatible with freedom. If we say the person is free, then freedom is compatible with some forms of interference.}

423999fa-3815-470c-9ef2-e0c81c65892b.summary: Does the absence of interference guarantee freedom?
423999fa-3815-470c-9ef2-e0c81c65892b.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is isolated on a deserted island with no possibility of interference from others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not necessarily free, as freedom involves more than just the absence of interference.}, {It is implausible that mere isolation or absence of others constitutes true freedom, as freedom typically involves the ability to engage with others and society.}

e36e4f86-aac1-4fc3-8455-100283a593d0.content: {There is a plausible principle that not all interference is dominating. This principle together with the idea that some interference can be justified or consensual entails that not all interference is arbitrary.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person consents to interference by others, such as in a contractual agreement. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the interference is not arbitrary and does not diminish the person's freedom.}

59f4c982-96a2-4d34-92a0-8c5d5f37d7a5.summary: Is freedom possible in hierarchical structures?
59f4c982-96a2-4d34-92a0-8c5d5f37d7a5.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is part of a hierarchical organization where they are subject to orders from superiors. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is not free or that they are free. If we say the person is not free, then hierarchical structures are incompatible with freedom. If we say the person is free, then freedom can exist within certain hierarchical structures.}

328d7d3a-5382-42fd-a17d-8e33169513a8.summary: Does freedom require equality of power?
328d7d3a-5382-42fd-a17d-8e33169513a8.content: {Consider a scenario in which two individuals have vastly unequal power, but the more powerful individual chooses not to interfere with the less powerful one. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the less powerful individual is not truly free, as their freedom is contingent on the goodwill of the more powerful individual.}, {There is a plausible principle that true freedom requires some form of equality in power relations. This principle together with the presence of power inequality entails that the less powerful individual is not free.}

1d6e870a-6b5b-4ddf-828c-a7f57930cc77.summary: Can freedom exist under constant surveillance?
1d6e870a-6b5b-4ddf-828c-a7f57930cc77.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is under constant surveillance by others, but no direct interference occurs. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is not free or that they are free. If we say the person is not free, then surveillance is incompatible with freedom. If we say the person is free, then freedom can exist under certain conditions of surveillance.}

be9be7d6-77d8-4fc0-b2b6-0379f040d4d2.summary: Is freedom merely a subjective experience?
be9be7d6-77d8-4fc0-b2b6-0379f040d4d2.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person feels free because they are unaware of the constraints imposed on them by others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's subjective experience of freedom does not equate to actual freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom is solely a matter of subjective experience, as objective conditions can significantly impact one's freedom.}

ba62e8ba-c90a-451d-bfbf-4a2420ea9a11.content: {There is a plausible principle that paternalism involves interference with a person's autonomy for their own good. This principle together with the idea that freedom involves autonomy entails that paternalism is a form of interference.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a government enacts laws to protect individuals from harm, such as mandatory seatbelt laws. Intuitively, we either have to say that individuals are not free or that they are free. If we say individuals are not free, then paternalism is incompatible with freedom. If we say individuals are free, then freedom can coexist with certain paternalistic measures.}

5f51aa34-8171-492a-8710-a6ccbec51433.summary: Does freedom require the absence of all constraints?
5f51aa34-8171-492a-8710-a6ccbec51433.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is subject to natural constraints, such as physical limitations, but no social or political interference. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not entirely free, as freedom involves more than just the absence of social or political constraints.}, {It is implausible that freedom requires the absence of all constraints, as some constraints are inherent to human existence.}

e7223837-246c-40b1-91e4-a56475552e66.summary: Can freedom exist if rights are violated by non-human factors?
e7223837-246c-40b1-91e4-a56475552e66.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Consider a scenario where a person is trapped in a natural disaster, such as an earthquake, which restricts their movement and access to resources. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free, even though no human has violated their rights.}

00974842-2620-42e5-8970-6e19d6626cf8.summary: Does the view account for positive rights?
00974842-2620-42e5-8970-6e19d6626cf8.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom also involves the ability to access certain basic goods and services, such as education and healthcare. This principle together with the view that freedom is only about non-violation of rights suggests that the view may be incomplete.}

405a73d7-0b77-42d9-a2b9-d9bd6dfaa3b9.summary: Is freedom possible in a society with systemic inequality?
405a73d7-0b77-42d9-a2b9-d9bd6dfaa3b9.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Consider a society where systemic inequality exists, such that certain groups have significantly less access to resources and opportunities. In such a society, intuitively we would judge that members of disadvantaged groups are not fully free, even if their individual rights are not directly violated.}

7fbe5491-9576-49c4-aa12-adf54f2509e7.summary: Can freedom be compatible with coercive contracts?
7fbe5491-9576-49c4-aa12-adf54f2509e7.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person enters into a contract under duress, such as agreeing to work for extremely low wages due to lack of alternatives. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free because their rights are not violated, or that they are not free due to coercion. If we say they are free, then we ignore the coercive context. If we say they are not free, then the view may not fully capture the nature of freedom.}

e180629c-822e-43a8-a8f7-f7295ad5b96e.summary: Does the view adequately address the issue of consent?
e180629c-822e-43a8-a8f7-f7295ad5b96e.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Consider a scenario where a person consents to an arrangement that severely limits their future options, such as selling themselves into indentured servitude. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free, even though they consented and their rights are not violated.}

267bbf82-ba25-442a-8e1c-e25e68a8382c.summary: Is the view consistent with the idea of collective rights?
267bbf82-ba25-442a-8e1c-e25e68a8382c.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {There is a plausible principle that collective rights, such as the right to a clean environment, are essential for individual freedom. This principle together with the view that focuses solely on individual rights suggests a potential conflict.}

d0bd871b-8777-4b3e-ae4b-3429ed069be1.summary: Can freedom exist in a surveillance state?
d0bd871b-8777-4b3e-ae4b-3429ed069be1.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Consider a scenario where a government conducts extensive surveillance on its citizens, collecting data on their private lives without directly violating their rights. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the citizens are not fully free, despite the absence of direct rights violations.}

fa7a610a-3c86-44b4-9dfb-2fdda9b3f17e.summary: Does the view account for the freedom of future generations?
fa7a610a-3c86-44b4-9dfb-2fdda9b3f17e.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom should consider the rights and opportunities of future generations. This principle together with the view that focuses on current individual rights suggests that the view may not fully account for intergenerational justice.}

02d9edda-4a22-4560-b582-3b72656eb282.summary: Is freedom possible in a monopolistic economy?
02d9edda-4a22-4560-b582-3b72656eb282.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Consider a scenario where a single corporation dominates the market, limiting consumer choices and controlling prices. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that consumers are not fully free, even if their individual rights are not directly violated.}

60fb9a95-297e-489c-8cd0-6101a87dda37.summary: Can freedom coexist with cultural oppression?
60fb9a95-297e-489c-8cd0-6101a87dda37.content: {Freedom is the protection of individual rights.}, {A person is free if their rights to life, liberty, and property are not violated.}, {Consider a scenario where cultural norms and practices severely restrict the roles and opportunities available to certain groups, such as women or minorities. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that members of these groups are not fully free, even if their individual rights are not directly violated.}

475625fb-c1d6-463f-90f7-93048ad8c834.summary: Can a person be free if they are manipulated without coercion?
475625fb-c1d6-463f-90f7-93048ad8c834.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is manipulated through subtle psychological techniques to make a specific choice without being coerced. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the absence of manipulation. This principle together with the scenario entails that a person can lack freedom even without coercion.}

3d0570f2-514e-4e56-ab39-a1bb4d73fc69.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is driven by an irresistible internal compulsion, such as an addiction, to make a choice. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is self-governing or that they are not. If we say the person is self-governing, then it seems implausible because their choice is not truly autonomous. If we say the person is not self-governing, then freedom as self-governance is challenged.}

578cdd73-92e7-4d37-93c5-3cdfe9604a7f.summary: Is freedom possible under social conditioning?
578cdd73-92e7-4d37-93c5-3cdfe9604a7f.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is raised in a society with pervasive social norms that strongly influence their choices without explicit coercion. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's freedom is compromised.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the ability to critically reflect on and potentially reject social norms. This principle together with the scenario entails that social conditioning can undermine freedom.}

7352a2c2-8fe6-43b6-ab61-39bb7466b444.summary: Can ignorance affect a person's freedom?
7352a2c2-8fe6-43b6-ab61-39bb7466b444.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person makes a choice based on false beliefs due to ignorance, without any coercion involved. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not. If we say the person is free, then it seems implausible because their choice is not informed. If we say the person is not free, then freedom as self-governance is challenged.}

d69a4987-f871-401e-9ecb-ad1edd19960e.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person must choose a job they dislike due to economic necessity, without any coercion from others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's freedom is limited.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires a range of meaningful options. This principle together with the scenario entails that economic necessity can limit freedom.}

d09d0916-50ce-482f-a6cb-6be24607bc3a.content: {There is a plausible principle that if determinism is true, then all events, including human actions, are determined by prior causes. This principle together with the claim that freedom is self-governance entails a tension, as self-governance implies some form of control over one's actions.}, {Consider a scenario in which determinism is true and a person makes a choice. Intuitively, we would judge that the person's freedom is questionable if their choice is determined by prior causes.}

659a7f67-330a-4479-897d-b6bfdd3f966d.summary: Can freedom exist in the absence of alternative possibilities?
659a7f67-330a-4479-897d-b6bfdd3f966d.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the ability to do otherwise. This principle together with the claim that a person is free if they can make their own choices without coercion entails that freedom requires alternative possibilities.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person makes a choice but could not have chosen otherwise due to circumstances. Intuitively, we would judge that the person's freedom is compromised.}

effb75bc-d6f7-40e1-9bce-a0b85b04c13b.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is heavily influenced by persuasive advertising to make a choice, without any coercion involved. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is self-governing or that they are not. If we say the person is self-governing, then it seems implausible because their choice is externally influenced. If we say the person is not self-governing, then freedom as self-governance is challenged.}

f9f1b287-1063-4c9f-be48-8066650c9dea.summary: Is freedom affected by lack of self-awareness?
f9f1b287-1063-4c9f-be48-8066650c9dea.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person makes choices without self-awareness, acting on unconscious biases without coercion. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's freedom is limited.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires self-awareness and reflection. This principle together with the scenario entails that lack of self-awareness can limit freedom.}

f51a898c-43d2-4a3c-860e-1370d2a9fec8.summary: Can freedom be compromised by emotional manipulation?
f51a898c-43d2-4a3c-860e-1370d2a9fec8.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is emotionally manipulated to make a choice, without any coercion involved. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not. If we say the person is free, then it seems implausible because their choice is emotionally manipulated. If we say the person is not free, then freedom as self-governance is challenged.}

ee88e267-1c23-4dbc-9a48-9d8f47575f75.summary: Does having capabilities necessarily equate to freedom?
ee88e267-1c23-4dbc-9a48-9d8f47575f75.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves not just having capabilities but also the absence of external constraints. This principle together with the idea that capabilities alone define freedom entails that someone could be considered free even if they are imprisoned, as long as they have internal capabilities.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to pursue education but is legally prohibited from doing so. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free to pursue education.}

6cb507e2-0a8f-4b80-b021-65f6d6206e13.summary: Can someone be free if they lack the opportunity to exercise their capabilities?
6cb507e2-0a8f-4b80-b021-65f6d6206e13.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has the capability to travel but lives in a society where travel is heavily restricted by law. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free to travel or that they are not. If we say the person is free to travel, then we ignore the practical restrictions they face. If we say the person is not free to travel, then having the capability alone is insufficient for freedom.}

11846889-96af-46ce-a475-71ec5e33fae1.summary: Is the mere possession of capabilities sufficient for achieving valuable functionings?
11846889-96af-46ce-a475-71ec5e33fae1.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to become a musician but lacks access to musical instruments. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person cannot achieve the functioning of being a musician.}, {There is a plausible principle that achieving valuable functionings requires not just capabilities but also access to necessary resources. This principle together with the idea that capabilities alone are sufficient for achieving functionings entails that someone could achieve functionings without the necessary resources, which seems implausible.}

8b32308c-8cb4-4ee5-800a-3eb364c2048f.summary: Can a person be considered free if they have capabilities but lack the motivation to use them?
8b32308c-8cb4-4ee5-800a-3eb364c2048f.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has the capability to pursue higher education but has no interest or motivation to do so. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free to pursue higher education or that they are not. If we say the person is free, then motivation is irrelevant to freedom. If we say the person is not free, then having capabilities alone is insufficient for freedom.}

d900f7ca-7dd8-41ab-af45-0239f4785c7f.summary: Does the capability approach adequately account for social and cultural influences on freedom?
d900f7ca-7dd8-41ab-af45-0239f4785c7f.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to choose their career but faces strong cultural pressure to follow a family tradition. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's freedom is constrained by cultural expectations.}, {It is implausible that freedom can be fully understood without considering social and cultural influences.}

cbfc2f9d-ad65-40ad-a7e4-1c7fc0cc651b.summary: Is it possible to have capabilities without having the freedom to use them?
cbfc2f9d-ad65-40ad-a7e4-1c7fc0cc651b.content: {There is a plausible principle that having capabilities does not guarantee the freedom to use them if external conditions are prohibitive. This principle together with the idea that capabilities define freedom entails that someone could be considered free even if they are unable to act on their capabilities due to external conditions.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to speak freely but lives under a regime that punishes free speech. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free to speak.}

ad01b32c-c910-4efe-b730-4aab7b76d761.summary: Does the capability approach overlook the importance of actual choice in freedom?
ad01b32c-c910-4efe-b730-4aab7b76d761.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has multiple capabilities but is coerced into choosing a specific path. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free to choose or that they are not. If we say the person is free, then actual choice is irrelevant to freedom. If we say the person is not free, then having capabilities alone is insufficient for freedom.}

f875e335-548a-45d0-9aae-cbfe7843566a.summary: Can a person be free if they have capabilities but face significant risks in exercising them?
f875e335-548a-45d0-9aae-cbfe7843566a.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to protest but faces the risk of severe punishment for doing so. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free to protest.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves not just capabilities but also the absence of significant risks in exercising them. This principle together with the idea that capabilities alone define freedom entails that someone could be considered free even if exercising their capabilities involves significant risks.}

e1dae280-7634-4da2-92fd-f1a87a147e8f.summary: Does the capability approach adequately address the role of personal autonomy in freedom?
e1dae280-7634-4da2-92fd-f1a87a147e8f.content: {It is implausible that freedom can be fully understood without considering personal autonomy.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to make life choices but is manipulated by others into making specific decisions. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's autonomy is compromised, affecting their freedom.}

e4d9c620-d2ec-494e-9a1a-c471d002b53f.summary: Is the capability approach sufficient for understanding freedom in contexts of inequality?
e4d9c620-d2ec-494e-9a1a-c471d002b53f.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves not just capabilities but also equality of opportunity. This principle together with the idea that capabilities alone define freedom entails that someone could be considered free even in a highly unequal society, as long as they have capabilities.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has the capability to pursue a career but faces systemic discrimination that limits their opportunities. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's freedom is constrained by inequality.}

0124374f-2f24-4c11-b926-074dd2e15d99.summary: Can individual freedom exist without community participation?
0124374f-2f24-4c11-b926-074dd2e15d99.content: {There is a plausible principle that individual freedom can exist independently of community participation. This principle together with the idea that freedom is participation in community life entails a contradiction.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person lives in isolation by choice and feels free. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is free despite not participating in community life.}

c3d51912-63c7-401c-91d3-3eb38c275638.summary: Does forced participation undermine true freedom?
c3d51912-63c7-401c-91d3-3eb38c275638.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is coerced into participating in community decision-making processes. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not free. If we say the person is free about this case, then it seems counterintuitive because coercion typically undermines freedom. If we say the person is not free about this case, then it contradicts the idea that participation in community life is freedom.}

320318be-5510-4bf4-98fa-cf060ed887c6.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom is an internal state of mind rather than an external condition. This principle together with the idea that freedom is participation in community life suggests that external conditions are necessary for freedom, which seems implausible.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person feels free due to their internal state, regardless of their participation in community life. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is free.}

30f805e0-955a-4eb5-a38e-39fdb3f24171.summary: Is community participation always beneficial for freedom?
30f805e0-955a-4eb5-a38e-39fdb3f24171.content: {It is implausible that participation in community life is always beneficial for an individual's freedom.}, {Consider a scenario in which community decision-making processes are oppressive or discriminatory. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that participation in these processes does not enhance an individual's freedom.}

0c8f7efa-e50c-4e2e-a594-570604d2f95d.summary: Can freedom exist in a non-democratic community?
0c8f7efa-e50c-4e2e-a594-570604d2f95d.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person participates in a non-democratic community's decision-making processes. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not free. If we say the person is free about this case, then it seems counterintuitive because non-democratic processes typically limit freedom. If we say the person is not free about this case, then it contradicts the idea that participation in community life is freedom.}

66d431be-b6ce-4fd4-8b76-c98cc60a6f68.summary: Does community participation require equal influence?
66d431be-b6ce-4fd4-8b76-c98cc60a6f68.content: {There is a plausible principle that true freedom requires equal influence in decision-making processes. This principle together with the idea that freedom is participation in community life suggests that unequal influence undermines freedom.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person participates in community decision-making but has significantly less influence than others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not fully free.}

188e3336-ff4d-4711-af2c-0607cc4612b6.summary: Can freedom be defined without community?
188e3336-ff4d-4711-af2c-0607cc4612b6.content: {It is implausible that freedom necessarily involves community participation.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person defines their freedom through personal autonomy and self-determination without reference to community life. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is free.}

e40265ad-7c6b-43ea-bc5e-df4efa2d5058.summary: Is freedom compatible with community obligations?
e40265ad-7c6b-43ea-bc5e-df4efa2d5058.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is obligated to participate in community decision-making processes. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not free. If we say the person is free about this case, then it seems counterintuitive because obligations typically limit freedom. If we say the person is not free about this case, then it contradicts the idea that participation in community life is freedom.}

a633f49d-37f9-40a1-acbc-e46c585a9729.content: {There is a plausible principle that participation in community life does not guarantee freedom. This principle together with the idea that freedom is participation in community life suggests that participation alone is insufficient for freedom.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person participates in community decision-making but is still subject to oppressive rules. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not free.}

dee03ef3-d156-421d-afa1-7509b0d0158b.summary: Can freedom be achieved through non-participation?
dee03ef3-d156-421d-afa1-7509b0d0158b.content: {It is plausible that freedom can be achieved through non-participation in community life.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person chooses not to participate in community decision-making to maintain personal autonomy. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is free.}

67e3aa0e-5cdb-4719-96a2-62ccf6044d09.summary: Can individuals truly define their own identity and purpose without external influences?
67e3aa0e-5cdb-4719-96a2-62ccf6044d09.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is raised in a highly controlled environment where all information and experiences are curated by others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person cannot truly define their own identity and purpose.}, {It is implausible that a person can create their own essence entirely independently of external influences.}

5c0ce884-9540-4abb-835c-fed28e33f562.summary: Is it possible for individuals to create their own essence given biological and psychological constraints?
5c0ce884-9540-4abb-835c-fed28e33f562.content: {There is a plausible principle that biological and psychological factors significantly influence a person's identity and purpose. This principle together with the idea that these factors are beyond an individual's control entails that individuals cannot fully create their own essence.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person has a genetic predisposition towards certain behaviors and preferences. Intuitively, we either have to say that this predisposition is part of their essence or that it is not. If we say it is part of their essence, then they have not created it. If we say it is not, then their essence is incomplete.}

fd062467-68d1-4a1f-95df-c354af433568.summary: Can freedom be equated with the ability to define one's own identity and purpose?
fd062467-68d1-4a1f-95df-c354af433568.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is free to make choices but lacks the ability to define their own identity and purpose due to societal constraints. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is free in some sense but not in the sense of defining their own identity and purpose.}, {It is implausible that freedom solely consists in the ability to define one's own identity and purpose without considering other aspects of freedom.}

28154b88-3799-4656-991c-572abfb3ed77.summary: Does the concept of existential liberty overlook the role of social and cultural narratives in shaping identity?
28154b88-3799-4656-991c-572abfb3ed77.content: {There is a plausible principle that social and cultural narratives play a crucial role in shaping an individual's identity and purpose. This principle together with the idea that these narratives are external to the individual entails that individuals cannot fully define their own identity and purpose.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person is deeply influenced by cultural norms and values. Intuitively, we either have to say that these norms and values are part of their identity or that they are not. If we say they are part of their identity, then they have not defined it themselves. If we say they are not, then their identity is incomplete.}

db1a7f6c-fe87-48e3-8689-9b9c377a3745.summary: Is the notion of creating one's own essence coherent given the influence of past experiences?
db1a7f6c-fe87-48e3-8689-9b9c377a3745.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person's past experiences have significantly shaped their current identity and purpose. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person cannot fully create their own essence independently of these experiences.}, {It is implausible that a person can create their own essence without being influenced by their past experiences.}

3134cd2c-fc62-4701-a07d-12ffe3007d1b.summary: Can individuals truly be free if their choices are determined by unconscious desires?
3134cd2c-fc62-4701-a07d-12ffe3007d1b.content: {There is a plausible principle that unconscious desires significantly influence a person's choices and actions. This principle together with the idea that these desires are not consciously chosen by the individual entails that individuals cannot fully define their own identity and purpose.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person consistently makes choices that align with unconscious desires. Intuitively, we either have to say that these desires are part of their identity or that they are not. If we say they are part of their identity, then they have not defined it themselves. If we say they are not, then their identity is incomplete.}

034bc8f6-d5dc-49af-8cd7-f0f754a248ee.summary: Does the concept of existential liberty adequately account for the role of chance in shaping identity?
034bc8f6-d5dc-49af-8cd7-f0f754a248ee.content: {Consider a scenario in which random events significantly alter a person's life path and identity. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person cannot fully define their own identity and purpose independently of these chance events.}, {It is implausible that a person can create their own essence without being influenced by chance occurrences.}

f6790562-5cb1-4021-8167-40a36a338a4c.summary: Is the idea of self-definition consistent with the existence of inherent human nature?
f6790562-5cb1-4021-8167-40a36a338a4c.content: {There is a plausible principle that humans have an inherent nature that influences their identity and purpose. This principle together with the idea that this nature is not chosen by the individual entails that individuals cannot fully define their own identity and purpose.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person exhibits traits that are considered part of human nature. Intuitively, we either have to say that these traits are part of their identity or that they are not. If we say they are part of their identity, then they have not defined it themselves. If we say they are not, then their identity is incomplete.}

50a54e4d-abba-4170-a8b7-8db502ac42a4.summary: Can the concept of existential liberty accommodate the influence of language on thought and identity?
50a54e4d-abba-4170-a8b7-8db502ac42a4.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person's language significantly shapes their thought processes and identity. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person cannot fully define their own identity and purpose independently of their language.}, {It is implausible that a person can create their own essence without being influenced by the language they use.}

4628a4bd-4ea9-45c5-acb0-9f4a8f83c755.summary: Does the notion of existential liberty neglect the impact of economic and social structures on personal freedom?
4628a4bd-4ea9-45c5-acb0-9f4a8f83c755.content: {There is a plausible principle that economic and social structures significantly influence a person's ability to define their own identity and purpose. This principle together with the idea that these structures are external to the individual entails that individuals cannot fully define their own identity and purpose.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person is constrained by economic limitations. Intuitively, we either have to say that these limitations are part of their identity or that they are not. If we say they are part of their identity, then they have not defined it themselves. If we say they are not, then their identity is incomplete.}

0a26d49c-a58c-4445-a4b6-f81483ebe709.summary: Does equal access to opportunities truly ensure freedom?
0a26d49c-a58c-4445-a4b6-f81483ebe709.content: {Consider a scenario in which two individuals have equal access to educational opportunities, but one has a severe learning disability. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual with the disability is not equally free to pursue educational goals.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires not just equal access but also the ability to utilize opportunities effectively. This principle together with the scenario suggests that equal access alone does not ensure freedom.}

9f006db3-c68a-43a1-a7ae-43a1f2be7ed2.summary: Can freedom be reduced to opportunities alone?
9f006db3-c68a-43a1-a7ae-43a1f2be7ed2.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has equal opportunities to pursue a career but faces significant social discrimination. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not free. If we say the person is free, then we ignore the impact of social discrimination. If we say the person is not free, then freedom cannot be reduced to opportunities alone.}

59c1d78c-4a92-4b8c-b591-014f5aafb15d.summary: Is equal opportunity sufficient for achieving personal goals?
59c1d78c-4a92-4b8c-b591-014f5aafb15d.content: {Consider a scenario where two individuals have equal opportunities to start a business, but one lacks the necessary skills due to inadequate prior education. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual without the skills is not equally free to achieve their business goals.}, {It is implausible that equal opportunity alone is sufficient for achieving personal goals if individuals lack the necessary skills or resources.}

345dfee8-4327-46fd-a2aa-710d27cdf2f1.summary: Does equal opportunity account for differences in personal circumstances?
345dfee8-4327-46fd-a2aa-710d27cdf2f1.content: {Suppose we have a case in which two individuals have equal opportunities to travel, but one has family obligations that prevent them from doing so. Intuitively, we either have to say that both are equally free or that they are not. If we say both are equally free, then we ignore personal circumstances. If we say they are not equally free, then equal opportunity does not account for personal circumstances.}

215d49c7-e842-478b-ab83-bb4908018a8d.summary: Can equal opportunities ensure freedom in the presence of systemic barriers?
215d49c7-e842-478b-ab83-bb4908018a8d.content: {Consider a scenario in which individuals have equal opportunities to vote, but systemic barriers such as voter suppression exist. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that individuals are not equally free to exercise their voting rights.}, {There is a plausible principle that systemic barriers can undermine freedom even when opportunities are formally equal. This principle together with the scenario suggests that equal opportunities do not ensure freedom in the presence of systemic barriers.}

93c2604c-db7b-48b4-882e-f12a5fef3533.summary: Is freedom merely about having opportunities?
93c2604c-db7b-48b4-882e-f12a5fef3533.content: {It is implausible that freedom is merely about having opportunities if individuals are unable to make meaningful choices due to external constraints.}, {Consider a scenario where a person has equal opportunities to choose a career but is coerced by family expectations. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free to choose their career.}

3ca32d6a-73ad-4805-a806-ef2792ff2396.summary: Does equal opportunity address power imbalances?
3ca32d6a-73ad-4805-a806-ef2792ff2396.content: {Suppose we have a case in which two individuals have equal opportunities to negotiate salaries, but one has significantly less bargaining power. Intuitively, we either have to say that both are equally free or that they are not. If we say both are equally free, then we ignore power imbalances. If we say they are not equally free, then equal opportunity does not address power imbalances.}

b69faf2e-e8f6-4d41-b952-8963f36fe36c.summary: Can equal opportunities compensate for historical injustices?
b69faf2e-e8f6-4d41-b952-8963f36fe36c.content: {Consider a scenario in which individuals from historically marginalized groups have equal opportunities today, but still face the consequences of past injustices. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that these individuals are not equally free to succeed.}, {There is a plausible principle that historical injustices can have lasting effects that equal opportunities alone cannot compensate for. This principle together with the scenario suggests that equal opportunities do not ensure freedom in the context of historical injustices.}

4a07e56e-90ff-4a8f-82f7-11c89dcdc7eb.summary: Is freedom possible without addressing economic disparities?
4a07e56e-90ff-4a8f-82f7-11c89dcdc7eb.content: {It is implausible that freedom is possible without addressing economic disparities if individuals lack the financial means to utilize opportunities.}, {Consider a scenario where two individuals have equal opportunities to attend college, but one cannot afford tuition. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual who cannot afford tuition is not equally free to pursue higher education.}

fe15782a-b66f-49f9-bd32-64ab4f87a442.summary: Does equal opportunity consider differences in personal motivation?
fe15782a-b66f-49f9-bd32-64ab4f87a442.content: {Suppose we have a case in which two individuals have equal opportunities to participate in a sports competition, but one lacks motivation. Intuitively, we either have to say that both are equally free or that they are not. If we say both are equally free, then we ignore differences in personal motivation. If we say they are not equally free, then equal opportunity does not consider differences in personal motivation.}

1c5ca812-6dad-4afa-ad87-2308f557a7f2.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person wishes to engage in an activity that causes harm only to themselves, such as substance abuse. Intuitively, we might judge that society has a responsibility to intervene to prevent self-harm.}, {There is a plausible principle that society should protect individuals from significant self-harm. This principle together with the idea that freedom is limited only by the prevention of harm to others suggests that self-harm should not be a reason to limit freedom, which seems counterintuitive.}

7cec0f47-9591-4679-b23f-a074ba97c106.summary: Does the Harm Principle ignore indirect harm?
7cec0f47-9591-4679-b23f-a074ba97c106.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person engages in an activity that does not directly harm others but creates conditions that indirectly lead to harm, such as spreading misinformation. Intuitively, we might judge that such activities should be restricted to prevent indirect harm.}, {There is a plausible principle that indirect harm can be as significant as direct harm. This principle together with the idea that freedom is limited only by the prevention of direct harm to others suggests that indirect harm should also limit freedom, which challenges the view.}

6120bbd2-c11f-4ae9-8a43-f379c9d7e79b.summary: Can the Harm Principle account for cumulative harm?
6120bbd2-c11f-4ae9-8a43-f379c9d7e79b.content: {Consider a scenario in which many individuals engage in a harmless activity that cumulatively leads to significant harm, such as environmental degradation. Intuitively, we might judge that such activities should be restricted to prevent cumulative harm.}, {There is a plausible principle that cumulative harm can justify limiting freedom. This principle together with the idea that freedom is limited only by the prevention of harm to others suggests that cumulative harm should also limit freedom, which challenges the view.}

b2befeb0-8235-488b-9b0b-466c7753ffa5.summary: Does the Harm Principle neglect moral harm?
b2befeb0-8235-488b-9b0b-466c7753ffa5.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person engages in an activity that causes moral harm, such as promoting hate speech. Intuitively, we might judge that such activities should be restricted to prevent moral harm.}, {There is a plausible principle that moral harm can justify limiting freedom. This principle together with the idea that freedom is limited only by the prevention of physical harm to others suggests that moral harm should also limit freedom, which challenges the view.}

c9ecf6bd-e2da-4721-8de7-ae1b146a1132.summary: Is the Harm Principle too individualistic?
c9ecf6bd-e2da-4721-8de7-ae1b146a1132.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person acts in a way that prioritizes their own freedom over community well-being, such as refusing to follow public health guidelines. Intuitively, we might judge that community well-being should sometimes take precedence over individual freedom.}, {There is a plausible principle that community well-being can justify limiting individual freedom. This principle together with the idea that freedom is limited only by the prevention of harm to others suggests that individual freedom should not always be prioritized, which challenges the view.}

855cb111-bd15-4362-9b07-9e3c8810c2dc.summary: Does the Harm Principle ignore future generations?
855cb111-bd15-4362-9b07-9e3c8810c2dc.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person engages in an activity that does not harm current individuals but poses a risk to future generations, such as unsustainable resource use. Intuitively, we might judge that such activities should be restricted to protect future generations.}, {There is a plausible principle that harm to future generations can justify limiting freedom. This principle together with the idea that freedom is limited only by the prevention of harm to current others suggests that future harm should also limit freedom, which challenges the view.}

2cb581df-1eb9-45c8-b596-4570e8c0bcf4.summary: Can the Harm Principle address non-physical harm?
2cb581df-1eb9-45c8-b596-4570e8c0bcf4.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person engages in an activity that causes non-physical harm, such as emotional distress or psychological manipulation.
